user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n:
```c
bool
MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n (const char *quoted,
                                     size_t quoted_len,
                                     const char *unquoted,
                                     size_t unquoted_len)
{
  size_t i;
  size_t j;
  if (unquoted_len < quoted_len / 2)
    return false;

  j = 0;
  for (i = 0; quoted_len > i && unquoted_len > j; ++i, ++j)
  {
    if ('\\' == quoted[i])
    {
      i++; /* Advance to the next character */
      if (quoted_len == i)
        return false; /* No character after escaping backslash */
    }
    if (! charsequalcaseless (quoted[i], unquoted[j]))
      return false; /* Different characters */
  }
  if ((quoted_len != i) || (unquoted_len != j))
    return false; /* The strings have different length */

  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n:
_MHD_static_inline bool
charsequalcaseless (const char c1, const char c2)
{
  return ( (c1 == c2) ||
           (isasciiupper (c1) ?
            ((c1 - 'A' + 'a') == c2) :
            ((c1 == (c2 - 'A' + 'a')) && isasciiupper (c2))) );
}
...
_MHD_static_inline bool
isasciiupper (char c)
{
  return (c >= 'A') && (c <= 'Z');
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (quoted_len == i)
        return false; /* No character after escaping backslash */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the code guards accesses to quoted[]. The loop condition (quoted_len > i) ensures the initial access quoted[i] is in bounds; when a backslash is seen the code increments i and immediately checks if i == quoted_len and returns false if so, preventing any subsequent access to quoted[i] beyond the buffer. Also no <string.h> functions are used here. Therefore Rule 21.17 is not violated.
